title: Python Programming 1
desc: This course is the first of an 8 month sequence introducing computer science through computer programming. This course will broaden your technical horizons, focus on systematic problem solving, and possibly change the way you look at the world. We welcome you and we hope you enjoy it.

labs.title: Hello World
labs.desc: Get prepared. In this module, you'll meet your teachers, learn how to set up VS Code, and build your first application.

instructions.title: Readings
list: Prior to starting the project, skim through Chapter 1 of the Perkovic textbook ; it provides some background, including some issues we talked about in class.
Lastly read sections 2.1 and 2.2 of the same text as it will help with the lab below.
After you've finished the readings, you are ready to begin.

instructions.title: Setup
list: Throughout these modules, we will be using a popular developer environment or IDE called VS Code. You can install VS Code for your respective OS (mac or windows) from the installation link here.
After installing VS Code, open the application and navigate to the extensions tab. (5th icon in the sidebar)
Select the first one--it should be the one by Microsoft
It should take a second. Once the Python extension is finished installing you should be prompted to restart your VS Code--go ahead and restart it.
That's it! Your VS Code is setup for the rest of the course!

instructions.title: Project Instructions
list: You should be met with a Getting Started page. Go ahead and select New File.
On the first line print "Hello World"

Save this file with your first initial, last name, and lab number. So if your name is Shafee Masud, save the file as: 
smasud_00.py
To run your code, open the terminal
You can locate the terminal in the navigation bar of VS Code. Once you find it, select New Terminal

Once you've opened a new terminal, type 
python3 smasud_00.py
. Replace the filename here with yours.
Check the terminal to see if it outputs "hello world"

labs.title: Factorial
labs.desc: In this module, you'll learn how to perform basic arithmetic, understand functions, parameters, and arguments. The primary function used throughout this module is called the factorial function (written in mathematical notation with an exclamation point, so `n factorial` would be n!).
